Atmos_Grid: Lambert conformal conic projection, hybrid sigma-pressure for the vertical
Atmos_Dyn: Dynamics is computed in the equivalent spectral space using bi-Fourier transforms. Two-time-level semi-Lagrangian semi-implicit numerical integration scheme
Atmos_CU: PCMT; Piriou et al. (2007) and Guérémy (2011)
Atmos_SW: Fouquart and Bonnel (1980) , Morcrette et al. (2008)
Atmos_LW: based on RRTM (Mlawer et al., 1997)
Atmos_details: Air–sea turbulent fluxes are derived from the ECUME (Exchange Coefficients from Unified Multi-campaigns Estimates) iterative approach (Belamari and Pirani, 2007)
Aerosols_details: TACTIC dataset for eval and GCM forcing for scen, 5 classes, 2D spatial pattern, vertical profile, seasonal cycle, temporal evolution
Land_details: No land use land cover change is taken into account
Ocean_details: Ice cover defined by a SST threshold
Lake_model: Flake (Moigne et al. (2016)), pronostic lake ice.
Urban_model: Urban areas are considered as rock (Daniel et al. 2019)
Other_comments: ALADIN63 v1 and v2 are identical. v2 indicates that the runs driven by the CNRM-CM5 GCM use the corrected version of the CNRM-CM5 Atmospheric-LBCs contrary to ALADIN53_v1

Atmos_Grid: Lambert conformal conic projection, hybrid sigma-pressure for the vertical
Atmos_Dyn: Dynamics is computed in the equivalent spectral space using bi-Fourier transforms. Two-time-level semi-Lagrangian semi-implicit numerical integration scheme
Atmos_CU: PCMT; Piriou et al. (2007) and Guérémy (2011)
Atmos_SW: Fouquart and Bonnel (1980) , Morcrette et al. (2008)
Atmos_LW: based on RRTM (Mlawer et al., 1997)
Atmos_details: Air–sea turbulent fluxes are derived from the ECUME (Exchange Coefficients from Unified Multi-campaigns Estimates) iterative approach (Belamari and Pirani, 2007)
Aerosols_details: TACTIC dataset for eval and GCM forcing for scen, 5 classes, 2D spatial pattern, vertical profile, seasonal cycle, temporal evolution
Land_details: No land use land cover change is taken into account
Ocean_details: Ice cover defined by a SST threshold
Lake_model: Flake (Moigne et al. (2016)), pronostic lake ice.
Urban_model: Urban areas are considered as rock (Daniel et al. 2019)
Other_comments: ALADIN63 v1 and v2 are identical. v2 indicates that the runs driven by the CNRM-CM5 GCM use the corrected version of the CNRM-CM5 Atmospheric-LBCs contrary to ALADIN53_v1

Atmos_Dyn: Non-hydrostatic regional COSMO model (COSMO model, 2022)
Atmos_CU: Tiedtke (1989)
Atmos_MP: Seifert and Beheng (2001), reduced to one moment scheme
Atmos_SW: Ritter and Geleyn (1992)
Atmos_LW: Ritter and Geleyn (1992)
Atmos_details: Other: Subgrid-scale orography scheme: Lott and Miller (1997); Schulz (2008)
Aerosols_details: Tanré et al (1984) climatology: spatially varying but temporally constant aerosol distributions are given for rural, urban, desert areas and the sea
Land_details: deepest soil mid-layer level is 11.5 m; dynamic moisture calculation is restricted to upper 8 levels until 2,86 m
Ocean_mode: Prescribed SST and SI, no further modification by RCM
Other_comments: Simulation carried out by KIT.

Atmos_Dyn: Non-hydrostatic regional COSMO model (COSMO model, 2022)
Atmos_CU: Tiedtke (1989)
Atmos_MP: Seifert and Beheng (2001), reduced to one moment scheme
Atmos_SW: Ritter and Geleyn (1992)
Atmos_LW: Ritter and Geleyn (1992)
Atmos_details: Other: Subgrid-scale orography scheme: Lott and Miller (1997); Schulz (2008)
Aerosols_details: Tanré et al (1984) climatology: spatially varying but temporally constant aerosol distributions are given for rural, urban, desert areas and the sea
Land_details: deepest soil mid-layer level is 11.5 m; dynamic moisture calculation is restricted to upper 8 levels until 2,86 m
Ocean_mode: Prescribed SST and SI, no further modification by RCM
Other_comments: Simulations carried out by BTU and DWD  with identical model version and configuration (except vertical layers and ToA) as for AFR-44 simulation above

Atmos_Dyn: hydrostatic model built on German Weather Service (DWD) Europa–Modell (EM) weather prediction model dynamics (Majewski, 1991) and ECHAM physics (Roeckner et. al., 1996).
Atmos_CU: Mass flux (Tiedtke, 1989) with modifications after Nordeng (1994) and Pfeifer (2006)
Atmos_SW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Atmos_LW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Aerosols_details: Tanré et al. (1984) climatology
Land_details: a tile-based scheme including annual cycle of albedo
Other_comments: The model releases REMO2009 and REMO2015 differ in internal technical aspects related to refactoring and improving the model code. The physical parameterizations and the implementation of the dynamics are the same. REMO2015 v2 refers to a rerun of the corresponding REMO2015 v1 simulation, which was necessary due to inconsistent model level and surface data in CNRM-CM5 GCM boundary conditions.

Atmos_Dyn: Non-hydrostatic regional COSMO model (COSMO model, 2022)
Atmos_CU: adapted version of the Tiedtke (1989)
Atmos_MP: single-moment bulk scheme with 5 species (cloud water, cloud ice, rain, snow and graupel)
Atmos_details: Other parameterization schemes described in main reference Leutwyler et al. (2017) based on Baldauf et al. (2011): radiative transfer scheme, multilayer soil model, and surface transfer scheme
Aerosols_details: AeroCom1 aerosol monthly climatology dataset (Kinne et al., 2006).
Land_compName: TERRA-ML with modified soil hydrology scheme (Schlemmer et al. 2018)
Other_comments: COSMO-crCLIM is similar to CCLM. Its main characteristics are that it runs on GPUs and includes the soil hydrology scheme of Schlemmer et al (2018). Other adjustments include changing the upper level damping to only relax the vertical velocity instead of all dynamical fields (Klemp et al., 2008)

Atmos_Dyn: Non-hydrostatic regional COSMO model (COSMO model, 2022)
Atmos_CU: adapted version of the Tiedtke (1989)
Atmos_MP: single-moment bulk scheme with 5 species (cloud water, cloud ice, rain, snow and graupel)
Atmos_details: Other parameterization schemes described in main reference Leutwyler et al. (2017) based on Baldauf et al. (2011): radiative transfer scheme, multilayer soil model, and surface transfer scheme
Aerosols_details: AeroCom1 aerosol monthly climatology dataset (Kinne et al., 2006).
Land_compName: TERRA-ML with modified soil hydrology scheme (Schlemmer et al. 2018)
Other_comments: COSMO-crCLIM is similar to CCLM. Its main characteristics are that it runs on GPUs and includes the soil hydrology scheme of Schlemmer et al (2018). Other adjustments include changing the upper level damping to only relax the vertical velocity instead of all dynamical fields (Klemp et al., 2008)

Atmos_Dyn: Dynamics from NWP model HIRLAM 7.0. Two-level hydrostatic semi-lagrangian semi-implicit scheme. Physical parameterizations are the same as the GCM ECHAM5 (like REMO).
Atmos_CU: Mass flux (Tiedtke, 1989) with modifications after Nordeng (1994) and Pfeifer (2006)
Atmos_SW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Atmos_LW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Other_comments: The different versions v1, v2, v3, are simulation versions due to necessary re-runs, not different model versions.

Atmos_CU: Tiedtke (1996)
Atmos_SW: CCM radiation scheme (NCAR CCM3, Kiehl, 1998).
Atmos_LW: CCM radiation scheme (NCAR CCM3, Kiehl, 1998).
Land_details: No subgridding (nsg=1)
Other_comments: Model version: v1 is a rerun following a minor bug in boundary conditions

Atmos_Dyn: Advanced Research WRF dynamics (Skamarock et al., 2008)
Atmos_CU: New Arakawa-Schubert with deep and shallow convection (Han and Pan 2011)
Atmos_SW: RRTMG (Iacono et al 2008)
Atmos_LW: RRTMG (Iacono et al 2008)

Atmos_Dyn: Advanced Research WRF dynamics (Skamarock et al., 2008)
Atmos_CU: New Arakawa-Schubert with deep and shallow convection (Han and Pan 2011)
Atmos_SW: RRTMG (Iacono et al 2008)
Atmos_LW: RRTMG (Iacono et al 2008)

Atmos_Dyn: hydrostatic, with HIRLAM dynamical kernel (Undén et al. 2002) utilizing a 2-level semi-lagrangian advection scheme.
Atmos_CU: EDMF-scheme (Siebesma et al., 2007) TODO:REVISAR shCU
Atmos_details: Baseline physics is taken from the IFS CY31r1 ECMWF package of physical parameterizations. MODIS inferred leaf-area index.
Aerosols_details: inferred from CAM inventory (except volcanic); historical and RCP pathways (van Vuuren et al., 2011; Lamarque et al., 2010; 2011); also used in evaluation Sulfate, particulate organic matter black carbon, sea salt, desert dust stratospheric aerosols, volcanic aerosol. Spatial maps and vertical profiles per species. Monthly variations and decadal trends.
Ocean_mode: prescribed SST and SI concentration; inferred from from reanalysis or GCM
Other_comments: Model versions: Simulations with RACMO22E_v2 are straight reruns of RACMO22E_v1 employing the same model system and parameter settings. Meaning of v2 depends on forcing GCM: i) MOHC-HadGEM2-ES: remapping of GCM-SST to RACMO grid erroneous in v1, corrected in v2 ii) CNRM-CERFACS-CNRM-M5:Atmospheric forcings derived from pressure level fields, because of error in CNRM-CM5 model level fields

Atmos_Dyn: hydrostatic, with HIRLAM dynamical kernel (Undén et al. 2002) utilizing a 2-level semi-lagrangian advection scheme.
Atmos_CU: EDMF-scheme (Siebesma et al., 2007) TODO:REVISAR shCU
Atmos_details: Baseline physics is taken from the IFS CY31r1 ECMWF package of physical parameterizations. MODIS inferred leaf-area index.
Aerosols_details: inferred from CAM inventory (except volcanic); historical and RCP pathways (van Vuuren et al., 2011; Lamarque et al., 2010; 2011); also used in evaluation Sulfate, particulate organic matter black carbon, sea salt, desert dust stratospheric aerosols, volcanic aerosol. Spatial maps and vertical profiles per species. Monthly variations and decadal trends.
Ocean_mode: prescribed SST and SI concentration; inferred from from reanalysis or GCM
Other_comments: Model versions: Simulations with RACMO22E_v2 are straight reruns of RACMO22E_v1 employing the same model system and parameter settings. Meaning of v2 depends on forcing GCM: i) MOHC-HadGEM2-ES: remapping of GCM-SST to RACMO grid erroneous in v1, corrected in v2 ii) CNRM-CERFACS-CNRM-CM5:Atmospheric forcings derived from pressure level fields, because of error in CNRM-CM5 model level fields

Atmos_Dyn: Walters et al. (2019)
Atmos_details: no lake component, no stochastic physics
Aerosols_details: MACv2-SP dataset (Stevens et al, 2017), total aerosol properties, 9 bands EasyAerosol (Voigt et al. 2014) RCP scenarios
Other_comments: v2 runs are using CNRM boundary conditions from pressure level 3D data. This is because CNRM model level 3D data (used in v1 version) do not correspond to the CNRM output available in the CMIP5 archive. No differences in the RCM, only a different source of atmospheric lateral boundary conditions.

Atmos_Dyn: Walters et al. (2019)
Atmos_details: no lake component, no stochastic physics
Aerosols_details: MACv2-SP dataset (Stevens et al, 2017), total aerosol properties, 9 bands EasyAerosol (Voigt et al. 2014) RCP scenarios
Other_comments: v2 runs are using CNRM boundary conditions from pressure level 3D data. This is because CNRM model level 3D data (used in v1 version) do not correspond to the CNRM output available in the CMIP5 archive. No differences in the RCM, only a different source of atmospheric lateral boundary conditions.

Atmos_CU: based on Bechtold-Kain-Fritsch (BKF) scheme (Bechtold et al., 2001) with revised calculation of CAPE profile according to Jiao and Jones (2008)
Atmos_SW: Savijärvi (1990) and Sass et al. (1994) with the consideration of CO2 absorption and an improved treatment of the water vapour continuum (Räisänen et al.,2000)
Atmos_LW: Savijärvi (1990) and Sass et al. (1994) with the consideration of CO2 absorption and an improved treatment of the water vapour continuum (Räisänen et al.,2000)
Aerosols_details: Single integrated class, parameterized aerosol effect on radiation fluxes,spatially uniform, static
Land_compName: a tile-based scheme with physiography based on ECOCLIMAP (Samuelsson et al. 2015)
Lake_model: Flake (Mironov et al., 2010) pronostic lake ice
Other_comments: Model versions: i) v1a is simply a re-run because a restart file to start the scenario experiment was taken from another simulations, ii) v2 and v3 are slightly tuned versions of v1 (some parameters) but parameterizations are the same. SN indicates spectral nudging.

Atmos_Dyn: Advanced Research WRF dynamics (Skamarock et al., 2008)
Atmos_CU: Kain-Fritsch-Eta (Kain, 2004)
Atmos_SW: CAM3 (Collins et al., 2004)
Atmos_LW: CAM3 (Collins et al., 2004)
Aerosols_details: Uniform background with vertical profile. Constant in time
Land_details: Corine Land Cover (CLC) 2006, remapped to IGBP Modis land categories (Bauer et al., 2019); HSWD 30” soil texture (Milovac et al., 2014)

Atmos_Dyn: Hydrostatic model built on German Weather Service (DWD) Europa–Modell (EM) weather prediction model dynamics (Majewski, 1991) and ECHAM physics (Roeckner et. al., 1996).
Atmos_CU: Mass flux (Tiedtke, 1989) with modifications after Nordeng (1994) and Pfeifer (2006)
Atmos_SW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Atmos_LW: Morcrette et al. (1986) with modifications for additional greenhouse gases, 14.6 μm band of ozone and various types of aerosols. Continuum absorption after Giorgetta and Wild (1995).
Aerosols_details: Tanré et al. (1984) climatology
Land_details: A tile-based scheme including annual cycle of albedo
Other_comments: The model releases REMO2009 and REMO2015 differ in internal technical aspects related to refactoring and improving the model code. The physical parameterizations and the implementation of the dynamics are the same. REMO2015 v2 refers to a rerun of the corresponding REMO2015 v1 simulation, which was necessary due to inconsistent model level and surface data in CNRM-CM5 GCM boundary conditions.
